titlestmt.titleproper: Lloyd E. Cotsen collection of Potter Family photographs,1865-1935: Finding Aid
titlestmt.author: Robert Lee Brutus III; Allison Hughes

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-26 16:45:25 -0500.

did.unittitle: Lloyd E. Cotsen collection of Potter Family photographs
did.abstract: This collection consists primarily of photographs taken by Rupert Potter (1832-1914), father of children's book author Beatrix Potter (1866-1944). It includes many portraits of Beatrix, of family members, and of friends. In addition, the collection includes studio portraits of Potter family members taken by various commercial photographers; a few photographs taken by Beatrix as aids for illustration; and photographs of animals and farmsteads in the Lake District related to Beatrix Potter Heelis' career as sheep farmer and land preservationist from the 1910s to 1940s.
did.physloc: This collection is stored at Firestone Library, RBSC South East, Cotsen.

prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Lloyd E. Cotsen collection of Potter Family photographs, Photograph number; Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Charlotte Whelan in June 2006. Finding aid written by Robert Lee Brutus III on July 30, 2006 and edited by Allison Hughes in February 2017.

bibliography.p: The Beatrix Potter Collection of Lloyd Cotsen. Cotsen Occasional Press: 2004.

acqinfo.p: Gift of Lloyd E. Cotsen, Class of 1950 in 2006.

The bulk of these photographs passed from Beatrix Potter to a family member at her death. They came into the possession of Beatrix Potter's cousin-once-removed Stephanie Duke and, after her death, into that of her husband, and still later into that of Col. Duke's second wife, Joan Duke. They were consigned to auction either by Joan Duke or her heirs. They were purchased at Sotheby's London EXCALIBUR 29/30 Nov 1989, lot 168, by Justin Schiller acting for Lloyd Cotsen. [information provided by email from Ivy Trent and Anne Wright]. In 2006, Cotsen made a gift of the photographs to the Library.

A number of photographs were acquired individually for the Cotsen Children's Library but have been united with this group; their original Cotsen accession numbers are noted in the item-level descriptions of the photographs.

appraisal.p: No materials were separated during 2006 processing.

accessrestrict.p: Permission to use the collection must approved by the Cotsen staff.

userestrict.p: Permission to digitize or photograph materials from the collection must be granted by the Cotsen curator. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Permission to publish material from the collection must be requested from the Associate University Librarian for Special Collections. The library has no information on the status of literary rights in the collection and researchers are responsible for determining any questions of copyright.

scopecontent.p: The Lloyd E. Cotsen collection of Potter Family photographs consists primarily of photographs taken by Rupert Potter (1832-1914), father of children's book author Beatrix Potter (1866-1944). Rupert Potter was a prolific amateur photographer who made many portraits of Beatrix, of family members, and of friends. He also photographed the landscape of the Lake District, Cumbria, England, where the family spent their summers. In addition to Rupert Potter's photographs, the collection includes studio portraits of Potter family members taken by various commercial photographers; a few photographs taken by Beatrix as aids for illustration; and photographs of animals and farmsteads in the Lake District related to Beatrix Potter Heelis' career as sheep farmer and land preservationist from the 1910s to 1940s. The Cotsen Children's Library also houses a wide array of drawings, manuscripts, correspondence, printed works, merchandise, and ephemera related to the life and career of Beatrix Potter. Some of these materials, along with the photographs, are described in Margit Sperling Cotsen, The Beatrix Potter Collection of Lloyd Cotsen (Cotsen Occasional Press, 2004).

The collection comprises approximately 1300 items. Almost all are photographic prints, including albumen prints; platinum prints; gelatin or collodion printing out prints; and silver gelatin developing out prints. Also included are a group of photographs of Bertram Potter's landscape paintings, and several envelopes originally used to store groups of photos.

arrangement.p: The photographs are arranged according to three series. The first series consists of portraits, which are arranged in the sequence used to describe them in the printed catalog of the Cotsen Potter collection. That is, they are arranged by portrait subject, and by date within each subject group. Although this mode of classification has the disadvantage of separating groups of images that were made on the same occasion with different subjects, every effort has been made to note such cross-references in the database entries. Photographs of animals are included in this series.

Rupert Potter's landscape photographs are arranged in chronological order and constitute the second series. Rupert Potter inscribed full dates on most of his photographs. Photographs that are dated only by month and year are filed at the end of the month to which they belong. Photographs dated only by year are filed at the end of the year to which they belong. Photographs from the same date in different formats are arranged smallest to largest, except when a smaller photograph is a cropped version of a print from a larger negative. In the latter case, the smaller print is filed immediately after the larger print from the same negative. At the end of this series is a small group of unsigned landscape images that cannot be confidently attributed.
The landscape series is followed by the third and final series, a group of photographs of Bertram Potter's landscape paintings.

accessrestrict.p: Permission to use the collection must approved by the Cotsen staff.

scopecontent.p: The first series consists of portraits, which are arranged in the sequence used to describe them in the printed catalog of the Cotsen Potter collection. That is, they are arranged by portrait subject, and by date within each subject group. Although this mode of classification has the disadvantage of separating groups of images that were made on the same occasion with different subjects, every effort has been made to note such cross-references in the database entries. Photographs of animals are included in this series.

arrangement.p: Arranged by subject and within subject by date.

scopecontent.p: Cataloger supplied title. Photographed by Maysons of Keswick. Photographers stamp in purple ink, verso: Enlargements unmounted,/ mounted or framed complete/ can be had from this/ copyright photograph./ price on application to/ Maysons/ photographers/ Phone:- 189 Keswick. Inscribed in ink by William Wilson: left: once again with Mrs Wilson/ Right: Moor tidy. with Miss Wilson/ Middle old Southward. [ampersand] young Billie/ Southward is mother to the other two. They were never beaten as a group of three sucking ews for three successive years/ a [illegible] group of ews, [ampersand] a do. of [illegible]. scopecontent.p: Rupert Potter's landscape photographs constitute the second series and are arranged in chronological order. Rupert Potter inscribed full dates on most of his photographs. Photographs that are dated only by month and year are filed at the end of the month to which they belong. Photographs dated only by year are filed at the end of the year to which they belong. Photographs from the same date in different formats are arranged smallest to largest, except when a smaller photograph is a cropped version of a print from a larger negative. In the latter case, the smaller print is filed immediately after the larger print from the same negative. At the end of this series is a small group of unsigned landscape images that cannot be confidently attributed.

scopecontent.p: Photographed during Lingholm stay. Title supplied from inscription. Inscribed in pencil by Rupert Potter: Rash Judgments/ Sep 8 1899/ R Potter/ Rydal Lake/ from N West. Title is a quotation from Wordsworth. Either from Tintern Abbey: Neither evil tongues, rash judgments, nor the sneers of selfish men, nor greetings where no kindness is, nor all the dreary intercourse of daily life, shall ever prevail against us. Or taken from Poems on the Naming of Places: IV, first line: A narrow girdle of rough stones and crags... ending: and POINT RASH-JUDGMENT is the name it bears. However, the latter poem refers to a location on Grasmere.

accessrestrict.p: Permission to use the collection must approved by the Cotsen staff.

Rupert Potter's inscription appears to name the estate visible through trees at right-hand side of image, but is difficult to read.

scopecontent.p: Cataloger supplied title. Inscribed in pencil by Rupert Potter: W.B. Potter / April 1904. Inscribed in ink, unknown hand: at Hill Top Farm / July 1948. Rupert Potter's inscription on two of the photographs in this group, absent any other marks of authorship, suggests the possibility that he made all of the photographs of Bertram's paintings. No external evidence is available to confirm this . Ink inscription of 1948 relates to the location of the paintings at that date, not to the date or location at which photographs were made.

scopecontent.p: Cataloger supplied title. No inscription. Rupert Potter's inscription on two of the photographs in this group, absent any other marks of authorship, suggests the possibility that he made all of the photographs of Bertrams paintings. Similarity in style and printing suggests this photo may have been made at same time as CTSN Potter 1281, dated Apr 1904. No external evidence is available to confirm this .

Similarity in style and printing suggests this photo may have been made at same time as CTSN Potter 1281, dated Apr 1904. No external evidence is available to confirm this . Similarity in style and printing suggests this photo may have been made at same time as CTSN Potter 1281, dated Apr 1904. No external evidence is available to confirm this . Printed from same negative as CTSN Potter 1291.

scopecontent.p: The third and final series consists of eight photographs of paintings by Bertram Potter and two receipts from photographer John Heelis to Beatrix.

arrangement.p: The eight photographs of Bertram's paintings are followed by the Heelis receipts.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Bertram Potter painting:stream emerging from a forest

accessrestrict.p: Permission to use the collection must approved by the Cotsen staff.

scopecontent.p: Cataloger supplied title. Inscribed in ink, unknown hand: at Hill Top Farm./ July 1948. Rupert Potter's inscription on two of the photographs in this group, absent any other marks of authorship, suggests the possibility that he made all of the photographs of Bertrams paintings. Possibly made at same time as CTSN Potter 1281, dated Apr 1904; though printed on a different paper, film format and setting appear the same. No external evidence is available to confirm this . Ink inscription of 1948 relates to the location of the paintings at that date, not to the date or location at which photographs were made.

did.unittitle: Receipt from John James for payment received from Mrs. H.B. Heelis

accessrestrict.p: Permission to use the collection must approved by the Cotsen staff.

scopecontent.p: Receipt from photographer John Jameson for 2 mounted 8x10 enlargements, 2 mounted 8x6 enlargements, 18 postcards, and postage. Sent from Penrith to Beatrix Potter at Castle Cottage, Ambleside. Subject of photographs not known, but probably livestock.
